metadata.title: Setting up an Integrated Development Environment for Python (Linux)
metadata.abstract: This lesson will help you set up an integrated development environment for Python on a computer running the Linux operating system.

body.p: Thanks to John Fink for providing the basis of this section. These instructions are for Ubuntu 18.04 LTS, but should work for any apt based system such as Debian, or Linux Mint, provided you have sudo installed.

div.head: Back up your computer
div.p: It is always important to make sure you have regular and recent backups of your computer. This is just good advice for life, and is not limited to times when you are engaged in programming.

ol.li: Open a terminal (Go to Applications, then type Terminal, then click on the Terminal icon).
Now type: sudo apt-get install python3
Enter your password, and then type Y to finish the install. Note that you probably have Python 3 installed already, so don't be alarmed if Ubuntu tells you that.

div.head: Create a directory
div.p: You will keep your Python programs in this directory. It can be anywhere you like, but it is probably best to put it in your home folder. Something like this in your open terminal window should do the trick:

div.head: Install Komodo Edit
div.p: Komodo Edit is a free and open source code editor, but you have many other text editing options if you prefer. You can download Komodo Edit at the Komoto Edit Website. Once you've downloaded it, open it with Ubuntu's package manager, extract it to your home directory, and follow the installation instructions. If you are following along with these instructions and have installed Komodo Edit, open the home folder, go to the Komodo-Edit-11/bin directory, and click on komodo.

div.head: Make a “Run Python” Command in Komodo Edit

ol.li: In Komodo Edit, make sure the “Toolbox” sidebar is visible.
Click the gear icon in the toolbox and select New Command.
In the top field type “Run Python File”
In the Command field, type: %(python3) %F. Then hit the OK button at the bottom of the Add Command window.

div.head: Step 2 – “Hello World” in Python
div.p: It is traditional to begin programming in a new language by trying to create a program that says “hello world” and terminates.

Python is a good programming language for beginners because it is very high-level. It is possible, in other words, to write short programs that accomplish a lot. The shorter the program, the more likely it is for the whole thing to fit on one screen, and the easier it is to keep track of all of it in your mind.

Python is an 'interpreted' programming language. This means that there is a special computer program (known as an interpreter) that knows how to follow instructions written in that language. One way to use the interpreter is to store all of your instructions in a file, and then run the interpreter on the file. A file that contains programming language instructions is known as a program. The interpreter will execute each of the instructions that you gave it in your program and then stop. Let’s try this.
